The input data is stored in a format similar to LibSVM file format, except that the **indices
are expected to be zero-based instead of one-based, and the column indices for each row are
expected to be sorted in ascending order**.
@formath

The id index in RowSparseNDArray is sorted in ascending order. This order is used in pull&push for encoding&decoding the key. It will be wrong if using random order during training now.

If you want to use random order, the encoding and decoding should be changed.

@anirudh2290 @cjolivier01 @reminisce

Yes it expects sorted order per row for indices. Otherwise the CSRNDArray is invalid, leading to calculation error. 
If you dataset is not sorted, you can first convert CSRNDArray to scipy and back to CSRNDArray, which always give you a valid CSRNDArray (after https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/pull/8362 is merged). 
e.g. 
```
batch.data[0] = sparse.csr_matrix(batch.data[0].asscipy())
```

For rowsparse the indices is also expected to be sorted. We're also adding a format checker in https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/pull/8259

@Garglesoap  When you call dropout on net, at each training epoch, it drops out random neurons in the layer with a probability of p (0.5 in my example). The first dropout drops out random neurons in the first layer (h1) in the example below, and the second one drops out random neurons in layer h2. By dropping random neurons, dropout prevents overfitting because it forces the network to learn combinations of more robust features instead of only fine tuning weights of features that may be insignificant in a normal neural network. As a result, it might / probably will take longer to train the network. 

Here is my fixed network:
```python
from sklearn.metrics import roc_auc_score, auc
import mxnet as mx

batch_size = 10000
train_iter = mx.io.CSVIter(data_csv="feature_train_v1.csv", data_shape=(50, ),
                   label_csv="label_train_v1.csv", label_shape= (1,), batch_size=batch_size,)

val_iter = mx.io.CSVIter(data_csv = "feature_validate_v1.csv", data_shape=(50, ),
                    label_csv="label_validate_v1.csv", label_shape= (1,), batch_size = batch_size)

data = mx.sym.Variable('data')
net = mx.sym.BatchNorm(data, fix_gamma=True)
net = mx.symbol.Dropout(net, p=0.5)
h1 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=net, name='h1', num_hidden=50)
net = mx.sym.Activation(data=h1, act_type="relu")

net = mx.sym.BatchNorm(net, fix_gamma=True)
net = mx.symbol.Dropout(net, p=0.5)
h2 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=net, name='h2', num_hidden=25)
net = mx.sym.Activation(data=h2, act_type="relu")

net = mx.sym.BatchNorm(net, fix_gamma=True)
h3 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=net, name ='h3', num_hidden=1)

softmax = mx.sym.LogisticRegressionOutput(data=h3, name='softmax') # Calculate the Loss !

model = mx.mod.Module(softmax)

# train the network
model.fit( train_iter,
            eval_data=val_iter,
            eval_metric= roc_auc_score,
            optimizer_params={'learning_rate':0.01, 'momentum': 0.9},
            num_epoch=9)

model.score(val_iter, roc_auc_score)
```

I fixed my error after realizing a few issues. 
* Since it is a classification problem, it helps to use metrics like AUC or cross entropy.
* Try using at least 3 fully connected layers. 
If you are doing a classification problem and are using sklearn's AUC function, it won't work for datasets that don't have enough negative labels (in a binary classification function). 

I found MXNet's website and tutorial a bit outdated and hard to follow when I was learning it around January. I had to experiment by reading the github repo - you'd probably have to do the same :| . 

I no longer use MXNet (I started using pytorch :) ... its nice!), but hope this helps.

Your code just made `b` an alias of `a` which isn't computation.

The following three examples show
1. the "what have you tried to solve it"
2. the snippet you posted with the addition of id check for `a` and `b`. it printed `True`.
3. the snippet where in-place assignment happens. the same id check printed `False`

   ...:
   ...: a = mx.random.normal(shape = (3, 3, 3))
   ...: a.attach_grad()
   ...:
   ...: b = 0
   ...: with mx.autograd.record():
   ...:     b = a+1
   ...: b.backward()
   ...: a.grad
   ...:

did you put in the linker flag `-llibopencv_stitching.3.3.1.dylib` by yourself? If so, try `-lopencv_stitching` instead and make sure its path appear in your `-L` paths.
Though even that may not be necessary since mxnet is not using the stitcher. Only `opencv_core`, `opencv_imgcodecs` and `opencv_imgproc` are needed.

By the way, this is not the true problem I want to emphasize. I just found 0.12 behaves a lot differently in autograd as 0.11. I have a piece of code that has been broken in 0.12 while it's working in 0.11, here is the snippet of what it's doing:

```
a is a mx.nd.array
a.attach_grad()
loss = 0
with autograd.record():
    for each target:
          loss = loss + LOSS_FUNCTION(a, target)

loss.backward()
Update gradient with a.grad
```
In 0.11, this works without any issues. But after switching to 0.12, this is broken with a.grad equals to zero. 

So I just want to understand any important changes in 0.12 about autograd.

@dai-dao You can use [`gather_nd`](https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/versions/master/api/python/ndarray/ndarray.html#mxnet.ndarray.gather_nd) op.

```python>>> import mxnet as mx
>>> a = mx.nd.array([[1,2], [3, 4]])
>>> index = mx.nd.array([[0, 1], [0, 1]], dtype='int32')
>>> mx.nd.gather_nd(a, index)

[ 1.  4.]
<NDArray 2 @cpu(0)>
```

@dai-dao There is an op called `scatter_nd` which can do the trick. However, this op will reset all the unindexed elements in the output to zero. So this might not be a desirable solution to you.
```python
>>> import mxnet as mx
>>> a = mx.nd.array([[1,2], [3, 4]])
>>> index = mx.nd.array([[0, 1], [0, 1]], dtype='int32')
>>> data = mx.nd.array([5, 6])
>>> mx.nd.scatter_nd(data, index, shape=(2, 2), out=a)
>>> a
[[ 5.  0.]
 [ 0.  6.]]
<NDArray 2x2 @cpu(0)>
```

How large is your weight matrix?  This is one of the mshadow-related legacy issues mentioned in https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/issues/7319#issue-247538605 
The problem is that 32 bit int is not sufficient to calculate the number of elements in a large matrix.. 

https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/include/mxnet/tensor_blob.h#L270
